page.title: 01Aldington and Bonnington
page.content: Aldington stands on an escarpment which once formed the Anglo-Saxon shoreline. Below,Bonnington stretches by way of small, sheep grazed, undulating fields to the Romney marsh. Aldington has a population of 1000, centred round the pub, shop/post office, fire station, butcher, school village hall and playing fields. The mediaeval church is 1 KM to the northeast amid a large area of cultivated arable land which is owned principally by one family. Southwards is an Evangelical free chapel. a home for Mentally Handicapped adults and a Detention Centre. Bonnington has a population of 100, 32 houses, a mediaeval church and a garage. The houses are scattered and many in both villages are over 200 years old. The people are a mixture of young families and retired.
